title: Incredible pictures you can’t miss
text:
What are these? Epic beauty ... Marcio Cabral’s stunning vista just one of the top entries. Picture: 'International Landscape Photographer of the Year’ Source: Supplied 
VIEWS from the places you’d rather be have judging this year’s International Landscape Photograph of the year tough, with keen Aussie snappers taking out the top spots. 
Australian photographer Luke Austin claimed the top $5000 prize from more than 2600 entries. 
Hailing from Sydney’s Northern beaches, but now based in Perth, Austin is a passionate landscape photographer who has travelled the world following his passion. 
Fascinated from a young age by his surroundings, the keen bushwalker has captured some of Australia’s wild natural beauty. 
“I am drawn particularly to wilderness photography and tend to use up all of my annual leave each year on trips hiking through Tasmania, my favourite place to photograph,” he said. Windswept ... Luke Austin’s winning image 2015 International Landscape Photographer of the Year competition. Source: Supplied 
This black and white shot of windswept trees in the rain was one of the winning images in his portfolio. 
“I enjoy the solitude of being in the landscape, surrounded by nothing but the natural 
environment. I find being out there with a camera in hand allows me to slow down and 
appreciate the finer details of the world,” he added. Wave rider Force of nature ... In third place for the International Landscape Photographer of the Year is Warren Keelan. Source: Supplied 
Another Aussie to claim a top spot is Wollongong-based Warren Keelan who won third place in with his powerful images of waves. 
“I’ve always had a fascination with nature, especially the ocean and its ever changing forms, and I am compelled to capture and share what I feel are special and unique moments in the sea. I love the raw, unpredictable nature of water in motion and the way sunlight brings it all to life, from both above and below the surface,” he said. Magnificent ... Warren Keelan’s second wave image won him third prize in this year’s International Landscape Photograph of the Year competition. Source: Supplied Abstract 
The competition also features prizes for individual categories like The Abstract Award which was won by Thierry Bornier of China. The light on these paddy fields, its delicate colours and intricate patterns make it is easy to see why this beautiful image is a winner. Like stained glass ... The Abstract category was won by Thierry Bornie. Source: Supplied Runner up ... 
Paul Zizka from Banff in Alberta, Canada, was a runner-up with this amazing shot of an adventurer climbing up a frozen waterfall. He has a passion for capturing the spirit of adventurers and finding unusual angles of common mountain subjects. As a landscape photographer, he particularly enjoys the challenge of capturing nature’s beauty at night and the unique features that come with a dark sky — stars, Northern Lights and dramatic silhouettes. Things are looking up ... Paul Zizka’s photo submitted to the International Landscape Photographer of the Year competition. Source: Supplied Remote beauty 
Another Australian runner-up was Matt Hutton who submitted this amazing image of a pool at Hamersley Gorge in Karijini National Park in Western Australia. Wild beauty ... Australian Matt Hutton was a runner-up in the International Landscape Photographer of the Year competition. Source: Supplied
